questions.text: A 65-years-old patient presented to the emergency with high grade fever, chest pain, increased respiratory rate and cough with expectoration. His sputum was sent to the laboratory for gram straining which showed the presence of pus cells and gram-positive cocci in pair. Which of the following will help in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bile solubility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bile solubility test is a key diagnostic tool for confirming Streptococcus pneumoniae , distinguishing it from other bacteria due to its unique colony dissolution in bile.
  • ➤ bile solubility test
  • ➤ Streptococcus pneumoniae

questions.text: 2. A 40-year-old man underwent kidney transplantation. Two months after transplantation, he developed fever and feature suggestive of bilateral diffuse interstitial pneumonitis. Which of the following is most likely etiologic agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cytomegalovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common viral cause of pneumonitis in post-transplant patients due to their immunocompromised status.
  • ➤ Other common CMV-associated conditions include:
  • ➤ Congenital CMV (e.g., microencephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, skin rash) Mononucleosis-like syndrome in immunocompetent individuals (simple tonsillitis) Chorioretinitis in AIDS patients Pneumonitis in transplant recipients.
  • ➤ Congenital CMV (e.g., microencephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, skin rash)
  • ➤ Mononucleosis-like syndrome in immunocompetent individuals (simple tonsillitis)
  • ➤ Chorioretinitis in AIDS patients
  • ➤ Pneumonitis in transplant recipients.

questions.text: With which of the following of viral hepatitis infection in pregnancy, the maternal mortality is highest:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hepatitis E

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis E is the most common cause of fulminant hepatitis in pregnant women and is associated with a high maternal mortality rate, particularly in the third trimester. It is crucial to prevent HEV infections by maintaining proper sanitation and avoiding contaminated water and food sources.
  • ➤ fulminant hepatitis

questions.text: True about Botulinum toxin:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Interfere with Cholinergic transmission

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin inhibits cholinergic transmission by blocking acetylcholine release, leading to flaccid paralysis. It is used clinically in small doses for conditions such as muscle spasticity, dystonia, and cosmetic procedures to reduce wrinkles.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from painful vesicular eruption at T-4 dermatome. The cause is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Herpes zoster

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes zoster (shingles) is characterized by a unilateral, painful, vesicular rash following a specific dermatome due to the reactivation of latent Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) . The T4 dermatome involvement indicates reactivation along the corresponding nerve. Remember that the rash never crosses the midline and often resolves with antiviral treatment, though postherpetic neuralgia can persist.
  • ➤ unilateral, painful, vesicular rash
  • ➤ Varicella-zoster virus (VZV)

questions.text: All statements are true about mycetoma except:

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery is important component of treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnosis can be made by examination of lesion

questions.correct_answer: A. Eumycetoma is caused by bacteria
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Eumycetoma is caused by bacteria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eumycetoma is caused by fungi, whereas actinomycetoma is caused by bacteria. The clinical triad of mycetoma includes swelling, discharging sinuses, and granules. Surgery is a key component of treatment, and the condition is typically painless.

questions.text: The insect given in the image below is vector of which of the following disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Visceral leishmaniasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Phlebotomus argentipes (sand fly) is the primary vector of visceral leishmaniasis , transmitting the promastigote form of Leishmania donovani. Remember the unique features of kala-azar: fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and LD (Leishman-Donovan) bodies in macrophages.
  • ➤ Phlebotomus argentipes (sand fly)
  • ➤ visceral leishmaniasis
  • ➤ promastigote

questions.text: XDRTB is defined as:

options.label: D
options.text: Resistant to INH + Rifampicin + Amikacin + Ofloxacin

questions.correct_answer: D. Resistant to INH + Rifampicin + Amikacin + Ofloxacin
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Resistant to INH + Rifampicin + Amikacin + Ofloxacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ XDR-TB is defined as resistance to Isoniazid (INH) , Rifampicin (R) , any fluoroquinolone (e.g., Ofloxacin), and one second-line injectable drug (e.g., Amikacin). Proper understanding of drug classifications and resistance patterns is crucial for TB management and treatment.
  • ➤ Isoniazid (INH)
  • ➤ Rifampicin (R)
  • ➤ any fluoroquinolone
  • ➤ one second-line injectable drug

questions.text: Wood’s Lamp used in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pityriasis versicolor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wood’s lamp is most commonly used for diagnosing Pityriasis versicolor , where the characteristic golden-yellow fluorescence is observed. It is also useful in detecting dermatophyte infections (e.g., ringworm) and some bacterial infections, such as erythrasma .
  • ➤ Pityriasis versicolor
  • ➤ golden-yellow fluorescence
  • ➤ dermatophyte infections
  • ➤ erythrasma

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for 3 days. On examination he was found to have delayed skin pinch time and dry oral mucosa. A peripheral blood smear revealed the following picture. Identify the pathogen involved:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key features for diagnosing Plasmodium falciparum in a blood smear are:
  • ➤ Plasmodium falciparum
  • ➤ Multiple ring forms within a single RBC. Accolé (headphone-shaped) forms. These are not seen in other Plasmodium species, making this the distinguishing factor for falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Multiple ring forms within a single RBC.
  • ➤ Multiple ring forms
  • ➤ Accolé (headphone-shaped) forms. These are not seen in other Plasmodium species, making this the distinguishing factor for falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Accolé (headphone-shaped) forms.

questions.text: All are Koch’s postulates except:

options.label: A
options.text: A microorganism should be constantly associated with the lesions of the disease

options.label: B
options.text: It should be possible to isolate the bacterium in pure culture from the lesions

options.label: C
options.text: Inoculation of such pure culture into laboratory animals should reproduce the lesions

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent dependably eradicates the organisms and cures the diseases

questions.correct_answer: D. Administration of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent dependably eradicates the organisms and cures the diseases
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Administration of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent dependably eradicates the organisms and cures the diseases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Koch's postulates are focused on proving causality between a pathogen and disease by deAmonstrating consistent presence, isolation, reproduction of disease in a new host, and re-isolation. The use of antibiotics or therapeutic intervention is not part of these postulates.

questions.text: Image depicted below belongs to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wuchereria bancrofti

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wuchereria bancrofti is recognized by its sheath and an empty tail without terminal nuclei. The mnemonic "World Bank Limited (WBL)" helps remember the three sheathed filarial species: Wuchereria bancrofti (empty tail), Brugia malayi (two nuclei at the tail), and Loa loa (continuous nuclei to the tip).
  • ➤ Wuchereria bancrofti is recognized by its sheath and an empty tail without terminal nuclei.
  • ➤ Wuchereria bancrofti
  • ➤ empty tail
  • ➤ The mnemonic "World Bank Limited (WBL)" helps remember the three sheathed filarial species: Wuchereria bancrofti (empty tail), Brugia malayi (two nuclei at the tail), and Loa loa (continuous nuclei to the tip).
  • ➤ "World Bank Limited (WBL)"
  • ➤ Wuchereria bancrofti (empty tail), Brugia malayi (two nuclei at the tail), and Loa loa (continuous nuclei to the tip).

questions.text: A child is presented with fever, conjunctivitis and bluish white spot-on buccal mucosa. Four days later, she developed rashes. What is the characteristic feature of the virus that is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ss- enveloped RNA virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles virus is an ss-RNA virus that is enveloped and belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family. The hallmark of measles is Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa, which are bluish-white spots opposite the molars and appear before the rash develops.
  • ➤ Measles virus is an ss-RNA virus that is enveloped and belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family.
  • ➤ Measles virus
  • ➤ ss-RNA virus
  • ➤ enveloped
  • ➤ Paramyxoviridae
  • ➤ The hallmark of measles is Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa, which are bluish-white spots opposite the molars and appear before the rash develops.
  • ➤ Koplik spots

questions.text: Identify the organism which shows effacement and attachment of intestinal cells as shown below?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) EPEC

questions.text: Fever with pneumonia, sputum smear showing broad based budding fungi with double contoured cell wall. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Blastomyces

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blastomyces dermatitidis is identified by its broad-based budding yeast morphology with a double-contoured cell wall, often referred to as the "figure of eight" appearance. This feature differentiates it from other yeasts, such as Histoplasma (narrow-based budding, intracellular) and Coccidioides (spherules instead of budding yeast).

questions.text: A patient with benign hypertrophy of prostate was admitted in the hospital for 3 weeks. He subsequently developed suspected catheter associated-urinary tract infection. The tip of the catheter was sent for culture and was grown on blood agar. After 24 hours, the blood agar shows the following appearance. What is the likely causative agent for the UTI?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proteus mirabilis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proteus mirabilis is a motile bacterium that exhibits swarming motility, forming concentric waves on agar plates. It is a frequent cause of catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CA-UTIs), particularly in patients with indwelling catheters.

questions.text: Correct sequence of bacterial growth curve:

options.label: A
options.text: Log phase – Lag Phase – Stationary phase – Decline phase

options.label: B
options.text: Lag Phase – Log phase – Stationary phase – Decline phase

options.label: C
options.text: Stationary phase – Log phase – Lag Phase – Decline phase

options.label: D
options.text: Lag phase – Stationary phase – Log phase – Decline phase

questions.correct_answer: B. Lag Phase – Log phase – Stationary phase – Decline phase
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lag Phase – Log phase – Stationary phase – Decline phase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of the bacterial growth curve is lag phase, log (exponential) phase, stationary phase, and decline phase. Each phase has specific characteristics: preparation and adaptation in lag phase, rapid division in log phase, equilibrium in stationary phase, and bacterial death in the decline phase.

questions.text: Eggs of which of the following parasite cause intense pruritus in perianal skin:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Enterobius vermicularis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enterobius vermicularis causes nocturnal perianal pruritus due to gravid females laying eggs around the anal opening at night. The characteristic eggs are planoconvex, non-bile stained, and transparent.
  • ➤ nocturnal perianal pruritus

questions.text: A 33-year-old sexually active male is having urethral discharge since last 8 months along with burning sensation while micturition. Gram staining smear of urethral swab Sample is showing following picture. The causative organism is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria gonorrhoeae appears as intracellular, Gram-negative, kidney-shaped cocci (diplococci) inside neutrophils on Gram stain and is a common cause of sexually transmitted urethritis.

questions.text: Which of this need V factor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) H. paraphrophilus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haemophilus paraphrophilus requires only Factor V (NAD) for growth, whereas other Haemophilus species may require Factor X (hemin), or both Factors V and X.

questions.text: HBV and HDV false is:

options.label: B
options.text: HDV causes more serious infection d/t superinfection

options.label: C
options.text: HDV cannot infect in absence of HBV

questions.correct_answer: D. HDV is a DNA virus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) HDV is a DNA virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is an RNA virus that requires HBV for its replication and is more dangerous in the case of superinfection, with a high rate of chronic hepatitis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with fever and altered sensorium for two days with the following rash on legs. Her BP is 70/50 mm Hg and neck stiffness is present. Lumbar puncture reveals cloudy turbid CSF with 4200 cells/uL, Protein level 168 and Glucose of 21 mg/dL. Which of the following correctly describes the organism causing this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Gram Negative Diplococci (kidney shaped), Oxidase positive

options.label: B
options.text: Gram Negative Diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose

options.label: C
options.text: Gram Positive cocci catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive

options.label: D
options.text: Gram Positive Diplococci (lanceolate), catalase negative, optochin sensitive

questions.correct_answer: B. Gram Negative Diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gram Negative Diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria meningitidis is a gram-negative diplococcus that ferments both glucose and maltose, is oxidase positive, and can cause fulminant bacterial meningitis with purpuric rash, septic shock, and Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: Helminth implicated in causing pernicious anemia is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphyllobothrium latum, the fish tapeworm, is the only helminth known to cause vitamin B12 deficiency and pernicious anemia due to its absorption of vitamin B12 in the intestine.

questions.text: Nontoxigenic C. diphtheriae changes to toxigenic C. diphtheriae by the help of bacteriophage. By which method this conversion occur?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) lysogenic Conversion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lysogenic conversion occurs when a bacteriophage integrates its genetic material into the bacterial chromosome, such as in Corynebacterium diphtheriae, converting it into a toxigenic strain capable of producing diphtheria toxin.
  • ➤ Lysogenic conversion

questions.text: Identify the vector involved in the spread of disease, whose peripheral smear is as given:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ixodid tick

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ixodid tick (Ixodes species) transmits Babesia parasites, which form the characteristic Maltese cross inside RBCs, leading to babesiosis.
  • ➤ Ixodid tick (Ixodes species)
  • ➤ Babesia
  • ➤ Maltese cross

questions.text: A person has received complete immunization against tetanus 10 years ago. Now he presents with a clean wound without any lacerations from an injury sustained 2.5 hours ago. He should now be given:

options.label: D
options.text: Human Tet globulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.correct_answer: B. Single dose of tetanus toxoid
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Single dose of tetanus toxoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A single dose of tetanus toxoid is sufficient for clean, non-tetanus prone wounds if the last tetanus dose was taken more than 10 years ago.
  • ➤ single dose of tetanus toxoid

questions.text: Staph. aureus causes vomiting in 6–8 hours. The mechanism of action is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vagal stimulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning involves pre-formed enterotoxin that rapidly stimulates the vomiting center and vagus nerve , causing vomiting and diarrhea within a few hours of ingesting contaminated food.
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus
  • ➤ vomiting center and vagus nerve
  • ➤ vomiting and diarrhea

questions.text: A neonate has hepatosplenomegaly. His urine was stained with Giemsa stain which revealed owl’s eye appearance inclusions. Which will be the most probable cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CMV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of owl’s eye inclusions in Giemsa-stained samples, combined with hepatosplenomegaly in a neonate, is characteristic of congenital CMV infection.
  • ➤ owl’s eye inclusions
  • ➤ hepatosplenomegaly
  • ➤ congenital CMV infection.

questions.text: Reduviid bug is a vector for the transmission of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chagas disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chagas disease is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi and is transmitted by the Reduviid bug (kissing bug) through its infected feces, leading to early-stage chagoma or Romana's sign and late-stage cardiac and gastrointestinal complications.
  • ➤ Chagas disease
  • ➤ Trypanosoma cruzi
  • ➤ Reduviid bug (kissing bug)

questions.text: A farmer presenting with fever off and on for the past 4 years was diagnosed to be suffering from chronic brucellosis. All of the following serological tests would be helpful in the diagnosis at this state except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Standard Agglutination test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Standard Agglutination Test (SAT) is useful for initial diagnosis but cannot differentiate between acute and chronic brucellosis. In chronic brucellosis, tests like 2-Mercaptoethanol (2-ME) test , Complement Fixation Test (CFT) , and Coombs Test are used.
  • ➤ Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)
  • ➤ 2-Mercaptoethanol (2-ME) test
  • ➤ Complement Fixation Test (CFT)
  • ➤ Coombs Test

questions.text: A farmer who is also having dairy farm with history of handling cows, presented to the dermatology OPD with ulcer over forearm with central black eschar. True statement regarding the likely causative organism:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) McFadyean's reaction positive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The McFadyean's reaction is a key diagnostic test for anthrax , showing separation of the bacterial capsule from the body of Bacillus anthracis when stained with polychrome methylene blue, giving a characteristic "capsule clump" appearance.
  • ➤ McFadyean's reaction
  • ➤ anthrax
  • ➤ Bacillus anthracis

questions.text: A Female had a thorn prick 5 years ago. She presented with a slowly growing 2 × 2 cm verrucous lesion which on KOH mount showed the following image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chromoblastomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a slow-growing verrucous lesion , history of thorn prick , and copper penny appearance (sclerotic bodies) on KOH mount are diagnostic of chromoblastomycosis , a subcutaneous fungal infection caused by pigmented fungi.
  • ➤ slow-growing verrucous lesion
  • ➤ history of thorn prick
  • ➤ copper penny appearance (sclerotic bodies)
  • ➤ chromoblastomycosis

questions.text: Which HPV causes Condyloma acuminate. Most common cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HPV 6 &11

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV 6 and 11 are responsible for condyloma acuminata (genital warts) , which present as warty, cauliflower-like lesions in the genital area. These strains are non-oncogenic and do not cause cancer.
  • ➤ HPV 6 and 11
  • ➤ condyloma acuminata (genital warts)
  • ➤ warty, cauliflower-like lesions
  • ➤ non-oncogenic

questions.text: Winter bottom sign is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) African trypanosomiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Winter bottom’s sign (posterior cervical lymphadenopathy) is a hallmark feature of African trypanosomiasis caused by Trypanosoma brucei and transmitted by the Tsetse fly .
  • ➤ Winter bottom’s sign
  • ➤ African trypanosomiasis
  • ➤ Trypanosoma brucei
  • ➤ Tsetse fly

questions.text: To prevent swarming the % agar in Nutrient agar has to be increased at least to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To prevent swarming motility of bacteria like Proteus spp. , increase the agar concentration to 6% , making the surface stony hard and resistant to bacterial movement.
  • ➤ swarming motility
  • ➤ Proteus spp.
  • ➤ agar concentration to 6%
  • ➤ stony hard

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is presented with necrotic pneumonia. Sputum culture reveals mucoid lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey medium. What is the organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Klebsiella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Klebsiella pneumoniae is a lactose-fermenting, mucoid colony-forming bacterium that causes necrotizing pneumonia , commonly seen in chronic alcoholics and produces thick, sticky colonies due to its polysaccharide capsule .
  • ➤ Klebsiella pneumoniae
  • ➤ lactose-fermenting, mucoid colony-forming
  • ➤ necrotizing pneumonia
  • ➤ chronic alcoholics
  • ➤ thick, sticky colonies
  • ➤ polysaccharide capsule

questions.text: The following is false about Adenovirus:

options.label: C
options.text: Hemorrhagic cystitis is due to type 11,21

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ssDNA virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenovirus is a double-stranded DNA virus , not single-stranded (ssDNA). It has an icosahedral capsid , and specific serotypes cause distinct syndromes like hemorrhagic cystitis (types 11, 21) and diarrhea (type 40).
  • ➤ double-stranded DNA virus
  • ➤ icosahedral capsid

questions.text: Identify the organism from its egg in the picture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Necator americanus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hookworm eggs (Necator americanus and Ancylostoma duodenale) are transparent and typically contain four blastomeres.
  • ➤ Hookworm eggs (Necator americanus and Ancylostoma duodenale) are transparent and typically contain four blastomeres.

questions.text: In HIV window period indicates:

options.label: A
options.text: Time period between infection and onset of first symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: Time period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV

options.label: C
options.text: Time period between infection and minimum multiplication of the organism

options.label: D
options.text: Time period between infection and maximum multiplication of the organism

questions.correct_answer: B. Time period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Time period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The window period is the time between HIV infection and the formation of detectable antibodies in the blood. During this time, antibody-based tests may yield negative results despite the presence of the virus, necessitating the use of tests that detect viral proteins like p24 antigen for early diagnosis.
  • ➤ window period
  • ➤ p24 antigen

questions.text: Pig tapeworm may cause dangerous disease than beef tapeworm because:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CNS involvement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) can cause neurocysticercosis due to the migration of larvae to the CNS after ingestion of eggs, making it more dangerous than Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm), which primarily causes intestinal taeniasis without systemic complications.
  • ➤ neurocysticercosis

questions.text: A 25-year-old female complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage since 2 years. She has history of asthma and allergy. On examination multiple ethmoidal polyps are noted with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions in both the nasal cavities. Biopsy is taken and the material is cultured which shown the growth of many hyphae and pseudhohyphae with dichotomous branching typically at 45. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of narrow, septate hyphae with acute (45°) dichotomous branching is a hallmark feature of Aspergillus infections, distinguishing it from Zygomycetes (such as Rhizopus and Mucor), which have broad, aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching (90°).
  • ➤ narrow, septate hyphae with acute (45°) dichotomous branching
  • ➤ Aspergillus

questions.text: A person presents with pneumonia. His sputum was sent for culture. The bacterium obtained was gram positive cocci in chains and alpha haemolytic colonies on sheep agar. Which of the following will help in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Optochin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus pneumoniae is identified by its gram-positive cocci in chains, alpha-hemolytic colonies, and sensitivity to optochin, distinguishing it from viridans group streptococci, which are optochin-resistant.

questions.text: Terminal spined eggs are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Schistosoma haematobium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Terminal spined eggs are characteristic of Schistosoma haematobium, which causes urinary schistosomiasis and is detected through urine examination.

questions.text: A rose gardener has multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics. Most common fungus responsible is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sporothrix schenckii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener’s disease," is caused by Sporothrix schenckii and presents as nodules and ulcers spreading along the lymphatics following trauma such as a thorn prick.

questions.text: False about mechanism of bacterial toxins:

options.label: A
options.text: Cholera toxin acts by inhibition of guanylcyclase

options.label: C
options.text: Shiga toxin act by inhibiting protein synthesis

options.label: D
options.text: Diphtheria toxin act by inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.correct_answer: A. Cholera toxin acts by inhibition of guanylcyclase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cholera toxin acts by inhibition of guanylcyclase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin does not inhibit guanylyl cyclase; it activates adenyl cyclase, leading to increased cAMP and watery diarrhea.

questions.text: True about antigenic drift:

options.label: D
options.text: Arises due to frame shift mutations

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leads to seasonal epidemics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antigenic drift refers to the gradual accumulation of point mutations in influenza A and B, leading to seasonal epidemics rather than pandemics.

questions.text: An army jawan posted in remote forest area following a tick bite had fever and headache. His fever was 104 °F and pulse was 70 per min. He had an erythematous lesion of about 1 cm on the leg surrounded by small vesicles, along with generalized lymphadenopathy at the time of presentation to the referral hospital. His blood sample was collected to perform serology for the diagnosis of Rickettsial disease. Which one of the following results in Weil-Felix reaction will be diagnostic in this clinical setting?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of spotted fever Rickettsial diseases (e.g., Indian tick typhus and RMSF) , the Weil-Felix reaction shows positivity for both OX-19 and OX-2 . Conversely, OX-K positivity is indicative of scrub typhus .
  • ➤ spotted fever Rickettsial diseases (e.g., Indian tick typhus and RMSF)
  • ➤ OX-19 and OX-2
  • ➤ OX-K positivity
  • ➤ scrub typhus

questions.text: EBV receptors is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) uses the CD 21 receptor on B lymphocytes to enter the cell, making it a key step in its pathogenesis and oncogenic potential.
  • ➤ Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) uses the CD 21 receptor on B lymphocytes to enter the cell, making it a key step in its pathogenesis and oncogenic potential.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dysphagia. On UGI Endoscopy a diagnosis of esophageal candidiasis was made. The organism obtained from the sample was cultured on a specialized media and the below finding were visible on microscopy of the culture. What phenomenon is shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Germ tube formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Germ tube formation is the hallmark test for the identification of Candida albicans and is not seen in other Candida species. It involves the formation of filamentous extensions in the presence of human serum.

questions.text: In patient with Malaria, if fever has periodicity of 72 hours, which one of the following is likely to be causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) P. Malariae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ P. malariae is the only Plasmodium species that produces a 72-hour fever cycle (quartan fever) , distinguishing it from other species that typically cause 48-hour fever cycles (tertian fever).
  • ➤ P. malariae
  • ➤ 72-hour fever cycle (quartan fever)
  • ➤ 48-hour fever cycles

questions.text: An HIV+ve patient with CD4 Count 20 cells/mm3 came with complaints of headache, mild neck stiffness and weakness suspected Meningitis, lumbar puncture revealed yeast with no pseudohyphae. India ink preparation shows capsule. Diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cryptococcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cryptococcus neoformans is a capsulated yeast that is identified using India ink staining and commonly causes cryptococcal meningitis in HIV-positive patients with low CD4 counts.
  • ➤ Cryptococcus neoformans
  • ➤ capsulated yeast
  • ➤ India ink staining
  • ➤ cryptococcal meningitis
  • ➤ HIV-positive

questions.text: Which is the first antibody synthesised in fetal life?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first antibody synthesized by the fetus is IgM (from around the 20th week of gestation), while the first antibody present in the fetal circulation is IgG, passively transferred from the mother.

questions.text: A child with bull neck and membrane over tonsil. What is mechanism of the toxin responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inhibits Elongation Factor-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2) , leading to cell death , which manifests as a pseudomembrane and bull neck in diphtheria.
  • ➤ diphtheria toxin
  • ➤ protein synthesis
  • ➤ ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • ➤ cell death
  • ➤ pseudomembrane
  • ➤ bull neck

questions.text: Women presented with dome-shaped warty lesions with a dimple at center on forehead since 2 months, similar lesions noticed in her daughter (image given) causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Poxvirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Molluscum contagiosum presents with dome-shaped, umbilicated lesions caused by the Poxvirus family . The hallmark feature is the central dimple in each lesion, making it a distinct clinical diagnosis.
  • ➤ Molluscum contagiosum
  • ➤ dome-shaped, umbilicated lesions
  • ➤ Poxvirus family
  • ➤ central dimple

questions.text: A person working in an abattoir presented with a pustule on his hand that progressed to form an ulcer. Smear is taken from the ulcer and sent to laboratory for investigation. Which of the following is the best stain to determine the causative agent of the ulcer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trichrome methylene blue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The McFadyean reaction (using methylene blue stain ) is the best method for identifying Bacillus anthracis , showing purple-blue bacilli with a pink capsule . The clinical clue of working in an abattoir and presenting with a cutaneous ulcer points strongly to cutaneous anthrax .
  • ➤ McFadyean reaction
  • ➤ methylene blue stain
  • ➤ Bacillus anthracis
  • ➤ purple-blue bacilli
  • ➤ pink capsule
  • ➤ abattoir
  • ➤ cutaneous ulcer
  • ➤ cutaneous anthrax

questions.text: A hospital worker is found to be HBsAg (+) ve. Further serum investigations showed HBe (+) ve and IgG anti HBc (+) ve. The given hospital worker is:

options.label: A
options.text: Acute Hepatitis B patient with High infectivity

questions.correct_answer: C. Chronic infection with high infectivity
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chronic infection with high infectivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In chronic Hepatitis B infection , HBsAg remains positive for more than 6 months, anti-HBc IgG is positive, and HBeAg positivity indicates high viral replication and high infectivity .
  • ➤ chronic Hepatitis B infection
  • ➤ HBsAg
  • ➤ anti-HBc IgG
  • ➤ HBeAg positivity
  • ➤ high viral replication
  • ➤ high infectivity

questions.text: Which of the following is ovo-viviparous?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Strongyloidis stercoralis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Strongyloides stercoralis is ovoviviparous (produces larvae instead of eggs), while other nematodes such as Ascaris , Enterobius , and Trichinella follow different reproductive methods.
  • ➤ Strongyloides stercoralis
  • ➤ ovoviviparous
  • ➤ Ascaris
  • ➤ Enterobius
  • ➤ Trichinella

questions.text: Fish acts as intermediate host in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) D. latum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fish tapeworm D. latum uses Cyclops as the first intermediate host and fish as the second intermediate host , while humans are the definitive host .
  • ➤ Cyclops
  • ➤ first intermediate host
  • ➤ fish
  • ➤ second intermediate host
  • ➤ definitive host

questions.text: Which of the following is microaerophilic?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Campylobacter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microaerophilic bacteria, such as Campylobacter, Helicobacter pylori, and Borrelia, require only 5% oxygen for optimal growth. Use the mnemonic "Help, Camp is Boring" to remember these organisms.
  • ➤ only 5% oxygen
  • ➤ "Help, Camp is Boring"

questions.text: Which of the following egg contains three pairs of hooklets and polar filaments but bile non stained?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) H. Nana

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The eggs of Hymenolepis nana are bile non-stained (transparent) and have polar filaments and three pairs of hooklets . Other tapeworm eggs, such as Taenia and Echinococcus, are bile-stained and lack polar filaments. Use the mnemonic "Neha" to remember the bile non-stained eggs.
  • ➤ bile non-stained (transparent)
  • ➤ polar filaments and three pairs of hooklets
  • ➤ bile-stained
  • ➤ "Neha"

questions.text: A woman with infertility receives an ovary transplant from her sister who is an identical twin. What type of graft is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An isograft is a transplant between genetically identical individuals , such as identical twins, making it the least likely to be rejected due to a perfect genetic match.
  • ➤ isograft
  • ➤ genetically identical individuals

questions.text: There has been an outbreak of food born salmonella gastroenteritis in the community and the stool samples have been received in the laboratory. Which is the enrichment medium of choice?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For Salmonella enrichment , Selenite F medium is used to selectively allow the growth of Salmonella while inhibiting other competing bacteria, particularly coliforms, making it the ideal enrichment medium in outbreak investigations.
  • ➤ Salmonella enrichment
  • ➤ Selenite F medium

questions.text: Patient is presented with cough with rusty sputum. On examination, lower lobe consolidation and bronchial breath sounds were heard. It gives a positive Quellung reaction. What is the probable Gram staining appearance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive, flame-shaped diplococcus that causes pneumonia with rusty sputum and gives a positive Quellung reaction due to its capsule swelling in the presence of specific antibodies.
  • ➤ Gram-positive, flame-shaped diplococcus
  • ➤ pneumonia with rusty sputum
  • ➤ positive Quellung reaction
  • ➤ capsule swelling

questions.text: Which is the mode of transmission and infective form of the parasite whose egg picture is given below?

options.label: B
options.text: Ingestion of egg contaminated in water

questions.correct_answer: B. Ingestion of egg contaminated in water
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic barrel-shaped, bile-stained egg with bipolar plugs belongs to Trichuris trichiura. The mode of transmission is ingestion of embryonated eggs from contaminated water or food .
  • ➤ barrel-shaped, bile-stained egg with bipolar plugs
  • ➤ ingestion of embryonated eggs
  • ➤ contaminated water or food

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with history of fever and enlarged lymph nodes and sore throat was suspected to have infectious mononucleosis and was ordered a Paul Bunnel test. Which of the following is the principle of the test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Paul Bunnell test is based on the principle of heterophile agglutination , where heterophile antibodies present in the serum cause agglutination of sheep or horse red blood cells, indicating infectious mononucleosis due to the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) .
  • ➤ Paul Bunnell test
  • ➤ heterophile agglutination
  • ➤ infectious mononucleosis
  • ➤ Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

questions.text: Ziemann dots:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ziemann dots are a hallmark of Plasmodium malariae infections and appear as fine granules within the infected red blood cells. Remember the mnemonics to differentiate between the dots associated with different species of Plasmodium.
  • ➤ Ziemann dots
  • ➤ Plasmodium malariae
  • ➤ fine granules

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with fever and cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral examination shows a grey membrane on the right tonsil extending to the anterior pillar. Which of the following medium will be ideal for the culture of the throat swab for a rapid identification of the pathogen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For rapid identification of diphtheria , Löffler’s serum slope is the enrichment medium of choice, facilitating the observation of characteristic metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Additionally, potassium tellurite agar can be used to detect black colonies.
  • ➤ diphtheria
  • ➤ Löffler’s serum slope
  • ➤ metachromatic granules
  • ➤ potassium tellurite agar

questions.text: All are true about Chagas’ disease except:

options.label: A
options.text: Romana's sign is a diagnostic feature of acute Chagas’ disease

options.label: B
options.text: Tsetse fly is the vector (Glossina palpalis)

questions.correct_answer: B. Tsetse fly is the vector (Glossina palpalis)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vector for Chagas’ disease (Trypanosoma cruzi) is the Reduviid bug (kissing bug), not the Tsetse fly . The Tsetse fly is the vector for African sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei.
  • ➤ Reduviid bug
  • ➤ Tsetse fly
  • ➤ Tsetse fly
  • ➤ African sleeping sickness

questions.text: Neil Mosser reaction or tunica reaction is useful to differentiate between:
questions.correct_answer: A. R. prowazekii and R. typhi
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) R. prowazekii and R. typhi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Neil-Mooser reaction is used to differentiate epidemic typhus caused by R. prowazekii (negative reaction) from endemic typhus caused by R. typhi (positive scrotal swelling).
  • ➤ Neil-Mooser reaction
  • ➤ epidemic typhus
  • ➤ endemic typhus

questions.text: All of the following interaction occurs between antigen antibody reaction except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Covalent bond

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antigen-antibody interactions involve non-covalent bonds such as ionic bonds, hydrogen bonds, Van der Waals forces , and hydrophobic interactions . Covalent bonds do not form in these reactions due to their strong, irreversible nature.
  • ➤ non-covalent bonds
  • ➤ ionic bonds, hydrogen bonds, Van der Waals forces
  • ➤ hydrophobic interactions
  • ➤ Covalent bonds

questions.text: Resistance to HIV infection occurs due to mutation of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CCR 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A mutation in CCR5 (called CCR5-Δ32) confers resistance to HIV infection by blocking the co-receptor binding and fusion step, preventing viral entry into the host cells.
  • ➤ CCR5
  • ➤ blocking the co-receptor binding and fusion

questions.text: True regarding H. influenzae growth:

options.label: A
options.text: Growth in MacConkey and blood agar but not chocolate agar

options.label: B
options.text: Growth in MacConkey and chocolate agar but not blood agar

options.label: C
options.text: Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium

options.label: D
options.text: Growth in MacConkey, blood and chocolate agar

questions.correct_answer: C. Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haemophilus influenzae requires factor V (NAD) and factor X (heme) for growth. It grows well on chocolate agar (where RBCs are lysed) but does not grow on MacConkey agar . Satellitism can be observed on blood agar when grown near Staphylococcus aureus due to the release of factor V.
  • ➤ factor V (NAD)
  • ➤ factor X (heme)
  • ➤ chocolate agar
  • ➤ MacConkey agar
  • ➤ Satellitism

questions.text: Swarming is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Clostridium tetani

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Swarming motility is observed in Clostridium tetani , Proteus species, and Bacillus cereus . It is caused by their highly motile nature due to flagella.
  • ➤ Clostridium tetani
  • ➤ Proteus
  • ➤ Bacillus cereus

questions.text: A patient admitted to an ICU is on central venous line for the last one week. He is on ceftazidime and amikacin. After 7 days of antibiotics, he develops a spike of fever and his blood culture is positive for gram positive cocci in chains, which are catalase negative. Following this, vancomycin was started but the culture remained positive for the same organism even after 2 weeks of therapy. The most likely organism causing infection is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Enterococcus faecalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus faecium are gamma-hemolytic streptococci (non-hemolytic) that form catalase-negative chains and are frequently responsible for hospital-acquired infections (HAIs) that are resistant to multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin .
  • ➤ Enterococcus faecalis
  • ➤ Enterococcus faecium
  • ➤ gamma-hemolytic streptococci
  • ➤ catalase-negative chains
  • ➤ hospital-acquired infections (HAIs)
  • ➤ resistant to multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl had splenomegaly, leucopenia, step ladder pattern fever and died in a few days. Longitudinal ulcers were found in intestine. What should be the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Typhoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Step-ladder pattern fever and longitudinal ulcers in the ileum are classic hallmarks of typhoid fever . Intestinal TB has transverse ulcers , and amebiasis and bacillary dysentery affect the colon , not the small intestine.
  • ➤ Step-ladder pattern fever
  • ➤ longitudinal ulcers
  • ➤ ileum
  • ➤ typhoid fever
  • ➤ transverse ulcers
  • ➤ colon
